TopicTitle: Video Wednesday: Scott explains rocket physics

Articles.Content: Many if not all of you have regularly heard expressions such as Ã¢â‚¬Å“TWRÃ¢â‚¬Â, Ã¢â‚¬Å“Delta VeeÃ¢â‚¬Â and Ã¢â‚¬Å“IspÃ¢â‚¬Â, but what do those actually mean? And how can you use them to your advantage like a true rocket scientist? Scott Manley explains how these concepts play a role in rocket physics, and shows you how easy it can be to calculate them by hand. This is a very informative video and a must see if you want to discover the rocket scientist in yourself. Still confused? The [http://forum.kerbalspaceprogram.com/forums/45-The-Science-Labs](**Science Labs** on the KSP forums is the place to ask how physics work!

Great choice in the video today. I actually just finished a course in Physics myself, so I actually understand a lot of this stuff now. Buuttt I'll probably just use kerbal engineer still ![:sticktongue:](//kerbal-forum-uploads.s3.us-west-2.amazonaws.com/emoticons/default_k_tongue2.gif)
That is a great video indeed, thanks to scott now I understand the relation between ISP and exhaust velocity.
It's certainly interesting to see it done, but I'm with Scott... I just let Kerbal Engineer do it for me.

Being a "spreadsheet guy" myself, I just love how all the math he did turned out juuuuuust right. Tells me once more this is not only a stupid rocket building game... ![:D](//kerbal-forum-uploads.s3.us-west-2.amazonaws.com/emoticons/default_k_cheesy.gif)

I like to know how things work, but I also like software that does the actual work for me. ![:D](//kerbal-forum-uploads.s3.us-west-2.amazonaws.com/emoticons/default_k_cheesy.gif)

And as always, I love the little anecdotes:

"Ok ok, metres, feet, pounds, kilos ... but we can agree with seconds, ja?!"
This is delightful material to cover. So much to learn, so much to teach.
